code_desc: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.
video_title: Probability Determining Chance
video_desc: This video is designed to help students gain a basic understanding of probability. This video is aligned with 7th grade CCSS standards. Please check out my ...

code_desc: Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Graph the solution set of the inequality and interpret it in the context of the problem. For example: As a salesperson, you are paid $50 per week plus $3 per sale. code_desc: Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.
video_title: 7GA2P1mp4
video_desc: Common Core State Standards mathematics video.
transcript: '  This is Common Core State Standards support video in mathematics. This standard states: Draw (freehand with ruler and protractor and with technology) geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from\\nthree measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle. Back in fourth grade, there was standard 4.MD.C.5a that gave students exposure to angles and angle measure. This fourth-grade standard states: An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of the rays by considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two rays intersect the circle. Also in fourth grade, a related standard was 4.MD.C.6 that talked about actually measuring\\nangles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Also in fourth grade, there is standard 4.G.A.1 that talks about drawing points, lines, line segments, rays, and angles. And notice that they do introduce the classifications of angles based on measure, those being right, acute, and obtuse angles. This should, in turn, help students identify triangles based on angle measures. So, that would give them some background and a little bit of experience with the terms that would lead to right triangle, acute triangle, and obtuse triangle. Note that this is the only Common Core standard where the term obtuse is mentioned. Also, the term acute only appears again at the high school level with regard to trigonometry. Another standard in fourth gradethis one is 4.G.A.2. This one talks about classifying two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specific size. Notice the last statement: Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles. Notice that when addressing standard 7.G.A.2, that seems like an appropriate time to classify triangles based on angle measure. which leads to the idea of the sum of the angles of a triangle being 180. This seventh-grade standard will help set the foundation for standard 8.G.A.2, which talks about two-dimensional figures being congruent to one another. Notice that this eighth-grade standard is the first mention of the concept of congruency in the Common Core standards. In eighth grade, we have this other standard 8.G.A.5 that talks about using informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum of triangles. If we switch our focus a little bit to the idea of constructing triangles from measures of sides versus angles, there is this high school standard, HSG.CO.C.10, that talks about proving theorems about triangles and that includes measures of interior angles of a triangle sum being 180, and the base angles of isosceles triangles being congruent. Notice that this high school standard is the only standard where the term isosceles appears. Also, the term scalene is not mentioned anywhere in the standards, and the term equilateral does not occur until the high school Geometry standards. when it comes to the classification of triangles based on the sides. seems like an appropriate time to classify triangles based on the lengths of the sides. In looking at the standard and these last statements dealing with the conditions that determine different contexts as far as the number of triangles, if we look at the idea of having more than one triangle formed, So, this standard here, 7.G.A.2, can help lay the foundation for the idea of similar figures that will come up in eighth grade. Again, this standard in eighth grade is the first formal mention of the concept of similarity in the mathematics content standards. But again, we can use this seventh-grade\\nstandard to start laying the foundation for that whether or not we use the actual mathematical terminology. Teachers should be able to find some type of software that can actually be used to measure angles, We have a protractor that we can use to measure angles, and so, this is a very useful tool that again, we can use. So, we take our protractor and we do that; and so we use our ruler to mark off that segment so that we have this ray. This is the beginning foundation for our triangle. So far, we have our one angle of 34 degrees. Okay, we have a little bit of a problem here. The way that the protractor is set up, I can measure the 71 degrees here, but I need the angle measure over here. So, what am I going to do? We can use the measure of 109 degrees over here, We can use this little trick of using the supplement of an angle to get the angle that we want. instead to get the 71-degree angle that we want as part of our triangle. So, now we would use our ruler and draw our segment. the angle measure is for this third angle up at the top. So, we take our protractor, put it in position, look at our measurement, and yes, it is 75 degrees. So, now we have our third angle being 75 degrees. then students are going to come up\\nwith different sized triangles. So, this sets up this idea of these triangles being similar. So, in fact, if you look at this in terms of the actual sides, we will have more than one triangle formed. So, this might be an example here of what some of the different triangles that students come up with would look like. Now, we can use this and link it to standard 8.G.A.4, but what we can also do is link this to standard 8.G.A.5 and use it to discover or informally prove that the sum of the interior angles of the triangle is 180 degrees. So, this is what we can do to do that. Pick out three different sized triangles, but all of them have the same three degree measures. Now, notice the three different angles here that come from three different triangles. We have our 71, our 75, and our 34, and if you add them up, that is 180 degrees and that is our straight angle here. Now, the standard talks about constructing triangles from three measures of angles, but we can throw the students a little\\nbit of a curve. What if we asked them to construct a triangle with angle measures 22 and 136? So, we do that. Take our segment, and so we have our angle, but what we can do is get the supplement 158, extend this other segment a little bit. There you go. Now the question is, well, that third angle in this triangle, what is the measure for that one? If we take our protractor and measure it, look what happens. they will end up making more than one triangle out of it. So, again, this might be an example of what they come up with, even though their lengths of the sides might be different sizes. Construct a triangle with angle measures 93, 64, and 43. Okay,  just like before, we have a little bit of a problem. I want my 93-degree angle on the left, not on the right. So, we have our 93-degree angle. and use this endpoint on the left So here we go. Extend your segment. So, we have our 43-degree and our 93-degree angles. So, now the question is the 64 degrees. Is that going to be that top angle? The protractor is saying 44 degrees Well, it turns out this is impossible. that can be formed with these three angles, and of course, what students can do is verify whether or not those three angles that were given add up to be 180 degrees. So, given similar tasks where the sum of the three angles is not 180 degrees, students will discover that no triangle is possible. So far, students have constructed triangles based on information regarding angle measure. The results included acute, right, and obtuse triangles. Students should note that when\\nonly given information about angle measures, the constructed triangles were similar even though no information was provided regarding side lengths, and students should also realize that the sum of the three interior angles of a triangle must be 180 degrees. code_desc: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example: If a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1/10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9 3/4 inches long in the center of a door that is 27 1/2 inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; this estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

code_desc: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions. For example, estimate the mean word length in a book by randomly sampling words from the book; predict the winner of a school election based on randomly sampled survey data. Gauge how far off the estimate or prediction might be.

code_desc: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. code_desc: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.
video_title: Sampling (statistics)
video_desc: In statistics, quality assurance, & survey methodology, sampling is concerned with the selection of a subset of individuals from within a statistical population to ...
transcript: 'In statistics, quality assurance, & survey\\nmethodology, sampling is concerned with the selection of a subset of individuals from\\nwithin a statistical population to estimate characteristics of the whole population. Each\\nobservation measures one or more properties of observable bodies distinguished as independent\\nobjects or individuals. In survey sampling, weights can be applied to the data to adjust\\nfor the sample design, particularly stratified sampling. Results from probability theory\\nand statistical theory are employed to guide practice. In business and medical research,\\nsampling is widely used for gathering information about a population.\\nThe sampling process comprises several stages: Defining the population of concern\\nSpecifying a sampling frame, a set of items or events possible to measure\\nSpecifying a sampling method for selecting items or events from the frame\\nDetermining the sample size Implementing the sampling plan\\nSampling and data collecting Data which can be selected Population definition\\nSuccessful statistical practice is based on focused problem definition. In sampling, this\\nincludes defining the population from which our sample is drawn. A population can be defined\\nas including all people or items with the characteristic one wishes to understand. Because\\nthere is very rarely enough time or money to gather information from everyone or everything\\nin a population, the goal becomes finding a representative sample of that population.\\nSometimes what defines a population is obvious. For example, a manufacturer needs to decide\\nwhether a batch of material from production is of high enough quality to be released to\\nthe customer, or should be sentenced for scrap or rework due to poor quality. In this case,\\nthe batch is the population. Although the population of interest often\\nconsists of physical objects, sometimes we need to sample over time, space, or some combination\\nof these dimensions. For instance, an investigation of supermarket staffing could examine checkout\\nline length at various times, or a study on endangered penguins might aim to understand\\ntheir usage of various hunting grounds over time. For the time dimension, the focus may\\nbe on periods or discrete occasions. studied the behaviour of roulette wheels at\\na casino in Monte Carlo, and used this to from that wheel. Similar considerations arise\\nwhen taking repeated measurements of some physical characteristic such as the electrical\\nconductivity of copper. This situation often arises when we seek knowledge\\nabout the cause system of which the observed population is an outcome. In such cases, sampling\\ntheory may treat the observed population as to predict the effects of the program if it\\nwere made available nationwide. Here the superpopulation is "everybody in the country, given access\\nto this treatment" - a group which does not Note also that the population from which the\\nsample is drawn may not be the same as the population about which we actually want information.\\nOften there is large but not complete overlap between these two groups due to frame issues\\netc.. Sometimes they may be entirely separate - for instance, we might study rats in order\\nto get a better understanding of human health, or we might study records from people born\\nin 2008 in order to make predictions about people born in 2009.\\nTime spent in making the sampled population and population of concern precise is often\\nwell spent, because it raises many issues, ambiguities and questions that would otherwise\\nhave been overlooked at this stage. Sampling frame In the most straightforward case, such as\\nthe sentencing of a batch of material from production, it is possible to identify and\\nmeasure every single item in the population and to include any one of them in our sample.\\nHowever, in the more general case this is not possible. There is no way to identify\\nall rats in the set of all rats. Where voting is not compulsory, there is no way to identify\\nwhich people will actually vote at a forthcoming election. These imprecise populations are\\nnot amenable to sampling in any of the ways below and to which we could apply statistical\\ntheory. As a remedy, we seek a sampling frame which\\nhas the property that we can identify every single element and include any in our sample\\n. The most straightforward type of frame is a list of elements of the population with\\nappropriate contact information. For example, in an opinion poll, possible sampling frames\\ninclude an electoral register and a telephone directory.\\nProbability and nonprobability sampling A probability sampling is one in which every\\nunit in the population has a chance of being selected in the sample, and this probability\\ncan be accurately determined. The combination of these traits makes it possible to produce\\nunbiased estimates of population totals, by weighting sampled units according to their\\nprobability of selection. Example: We want to estimate the total income\\nof adults living in a given street. We visit each household in that street, identify all\\nadults living there, and randomly select one adult from each household.. We then interview\\nthe selected person and find their income. People living on their own are certain to\\nbe selected, so we simply add their income to our estimate of the total. But a person\\nliving in a household of two adults has only a one-in-two chance of selection. To reflect\\nthis, when we come to such a household, we In the above example, not everybody has the\\nsame probability of selection; what makes element in the population does have the same\\nprobability of selection, this is known as because all sampled units are given the same\\nweight. Probability sampling includes: Simple Random\\nSampling, Systematic Sampling, Stratified Sampling, Probability Proportional to Size\\nSampling, and Cluster or Multistage Sampling. These various ways of probability sampling\\nhave two things in common: Every element has a known nonzero probability\\nof being sampled and involves random selection at some point.\\nNonprobability sampling is any sampling method where some elements of the population have\\nno chance of selection, or where the probability on assumptions regarding the population of\\ninterest, which forms the criteria for selection. Hence, because the selection of elements is\\nnonrandom, nonprobability sampling does not allow the estimation of sampling errors. These\\nconditions give rise to exclusion bias, placing limits on how much information a sample can\\nprovide about the population. Information about the relationship between sample and\\npopulation is limited, making it difficult to extrapolate from the sample to the population. Example: We visit every household in a given\\nstreet, and interview the first person to answer the door. In any household with more\\nthan one occupant, this is a nonprobability to calculate these probabilities. Nonprobability sampling methods include accidental\\nsampling, quota sampling and purposive sampling. In addition, nonresponse effects may turn\\nany probability design into a nonprobability design if the characteristics of nonresponse\\nare not well understood, since nonresponse Sampling methods\\nWithin any of the types of frame identified above, a variety of sampling methods can be\\nemployed, individually or in combination. Factors commonly influencing the choice between\\nthese designs include: Nature and quality of the frame\\nAvailability of auxiliary information about units on the frame\\nAccuracy requirements, and the need to measure accuracy\\nWhether detailed analysis of the sample is expected\\nCost/operational concerns Simple random sampling In a simple random sample of a given size,\\nall such subsets of the frame are given an equal probability. Furthermore, any given\\npair of elements has the same chance of selection as any other such pair. This minimises bias\\nand simplifies analysis of results. In particular, the variance between individual results within\\nthe sample is a good indicator of variance in the overall population, which makes it\\nrelatively easy to estimate the accuracy of results.\\nHowever, SRS can be vulnerable to sampling the makeup of the population. For instance,\\na simple random sample of ten people from a given country will on average produce five\\nmen and five women, but any given trial is likely to overrepresent one sex and underrepresent\\nthe other., attempt to overcome this problem by "using information about the population"\\nto choose a more "representative" sample. SRS may also be cumbersome and tedious when\\nsampling from an unusually large target population. In some cases, investigators are interested\\nin "research questions specific" to subgroups of the population. For example, researchers\\nmight be interested in examining whether cognitive ability as a predictor of job performance\\nis equally applicable across racial groups. SRS cannot accommodate the needs of researchers\\nin this situation because it does not provide subsamples of the population. "Stratified\\nsampling" addresses this weakness of SRS. Systematic sampling\\nSystematic sampling relies on arranging the study population according to some ordering\\nscheme and then selecting elements at regular intervals through that ordered list. Systematic\\nsampling involves a random start and then proceeds with the selection of every kth element\\nfrom then onwards. In this case, k=(population size/sample size). It is important that the\\nstarting point is not automatically the first in the list, but is instead randomly chosen\\nfrom within the first to the kth element in the list. A simple example would be to select\\nevery 10th name from the telephone directory. As long as the starting point is randomized,\\nsystematic sampling is a type of probability sampling. It is easy to implement and the\\nstratification induced can make it efficient, if the variable by which the list is ordered\\nis correlated with the variable of interest. For example, suppose we wish to sample people\\nfrom a long street that starts in a poor area and ends in an expensive district. A simple\\nrandom selection of addresses from this street could easily end up with too many from the\\nhigh end and too few from the low end, leading to an unrepresentative sample. Selecting every\\n10th street number along the street ensures that the sample is spread evenly along the\\nlength of the street, representing all of these districts. (Note that if we always start\\nat house #1 and end at #991, the sample is slightly biased towards the low end; by randomly\\nselecting the start between #1 and #10, this bias is eliminated.\\nHowever, systematic sampling is especially vulnerable to periodicities in the list. If\\nperiodicity is present and the period is a multiple or factor of the interval used, the\\nsample is especially likely to be unrepresentative of the overall population, making the scheme\\nless accurate than simple random sampling. For example, consider a street where the odd-numbered\\nhouses are all on the north side of the road, and the even-numbered houses are all on the\\nsouth side. Under the sampling scheme given above, it is impossible to get a representative\\nsample; either the houses sampled will all be from the odd-numbered, expensive side,\\nor they will all be from the even-numbered, cheap side.\\nAnother drawback of systematic sampling is that even in scenarios where it is more accurate\\nthan SRS, its theoretical properties make it difficult to quantify that accuracy.\\nAs described above, systematic sampling is probabilities - e.g. the set {4,14,24,...,994}\\nhas a one-in-ten probability of selection, but the set {4,13,24,34,...} has zero probability\\nof selection. Systematic sampling can also be adapted to\\na non-EPS approach; for an example, see discussion of PPS samples below.\\nStratified sampling Where the population embraces a number of\\ndistinct categories, the frame can be organized by these categories into separate "strata."\\nEach stratum is then sampled as an independent sub-population, out of which individual elements\\ncan be randomly selected. There are several potential benefits to stratified sampling.\\nFirst, dividing the population into distinct, independent strata can enable researchers\\nto draw inferences about specific subgroups that may be lost in a more generalized random\\nsample. Second, utilizing a stratified sampling method\\ncan lead to more efficient statistical estimates. Even if a stratified sampling approach does\\nnot lead to increased statistical efficiency, such a tactic will not result in less efficiency\\nthan would simple random sampling, provided Third, it is sometimes the case that data\\nare more readily available for individual, pre-existing strata within a population than\\nfor the overall population; in such cases, using a stratified sampling approach may be\\nmore convenient than aggregating data across groups.\\nFinally, since each stratum is treated as an independent population, different sampling\\napproaches can be applied to different strata, potentially enabling researchers to use the\\napproach best suited for each identified subgroup within the population.\\nThere are, however, some potential drawbacks to using stratified sampling. First, identifying\\nstrata and implementing such an approach can increase the cost and complexity of sample\\nselection, as well as leading to increased complexity of population estimates. Second,\\nwhen examining multiple criteria, stratifying variables may be related to some, but not\\nto others, further complicating the design, and potentially reducing the utility of the\\nstrata. Finally, in some cases, stratified sampling can potentially require a larger\\nsample than would other methods (although in most cases, the required sample size would\\nbe no larger than would be required for simple random sampling.\\nA stratified sampling approach is most effective when three conditions are met\\nVariability within strata are minimized Variability between strata are maximized\\nThe variables upon which the population is stratified are strongly correlated with the\\ndesired dependent variable. Advantages over other sampling methods\\nFocuses on important subpopulations and ignores irrelevant ones.\\nAllows use of different sampling techniques for different subpopulations.\\nImproves the accuracy/efficiency of estimation. Permits greater balancing of statistical power\\nof tests of differences between strata by sampling equal numbers from strata varying\\nwidely in size. Disadvantages\\nRequires selection of relevant stratification variables which can be difficult.\\nIs not useful when there are no homogeneous subgroups.\\nCan be expensive to implement. Poststratification\\nStratification is sometimes introduced after the sampling phase in a process called "poststratification".\\nThis approach is typically implemented due to a lack of prior knowledge of an appropriate\\nstratifying variable or when the experimenter lacks the necessary information to create\\na stratifying variable during the sampling phase. Although the method is susceptible\\nto the pitfalls of post hoc approaches, it can provide several benefits in the right\\nsituation. Implementation usually follows a simple random sample. In addition to allowing\\nfor stratification on an ancillary variable, poststratification can be used to implement\\nweighting, which can improve the precision Choice-based sampling is one of the stratified\\nsampling strategies. In choice-based sampling, the data are stratified on the target and\\na sample is taken from each stratum so that the rare target class will be more represented\\nin the sample. The model is then built on this biased sample. The effects of the input\\nvariables on the target are often estimated with more precision with the choice-based\\nsample even when a smaller overall sample size is taken, compared to a random sample.\\nThe results usually must be adjusted to correct for the oversampling.\\nProbability-proportional-to-size sampling In some cases the sample designer has access\\nto an "auxiliary variable" or "size measure", believed to be correlated to the variable\\nof interest, for each element in the population. These data can be used to improve accuracy\\nin sample design. One option is to use the auxiliary variable as a basis for stratification,\\nas discussed above. Another option is probability proportional\\nto size sampling, in which the selection probability for each element is set to be proportional\\nto its size measure, up to a maximum of 1. In a simple PPS design, these selection probabilities\\ncan then be used as the basis for Poisson sampling. However, this has the drawback of\\nvariable sample size, and different portions of the population may still be over- or under-represented\\ndue to chance variation in selections. Systematic sampling theory can be used to\\ncreate a probability proportionate to size sample. This is done by treating each count\\nwithin the size variable as a single sampling unit. Samples are then identified by selecting\\nat even intervals among these counts within the size variable. This method is sometimes\\ncalled PPS-sequential or monetary unit sampling in the case of audits or forensic sampling. Example: Suppose we have six schools with\\npopulations of 150, 180, 200, 220, 260, and\\xa0490 students respectively, and we want to use\\nstudent population as the basis for a PPS sample of size three. To do this, we could\\nallocate the first school numbers 1\\xa0to\\xa0150, the second school 151 to 330\\xa0(=\\xa0150\\xa0+\\xa0180),\\nthe third school 331 to 530, and so on to the last school. We then generate a random\\nstart between 1 and 500 and count through the school populations by multiples of 500.\\nIf our random start was 137, we would select the schools which have been allocated numbers\\n137, 637, and\\xa01137, i.e. the first, fourth, and sixth schools. The PPS approach can improve accuracy for\\na given sample size by concentrating sample on large elements that have the greatest impact\\non population estimates. PPS sampling is commonly used for surveys of businesses, where element\\nsize varies greatly and auxiliary information is often availablefor instance, a survey\\nattempting to measure the number of guest-nights cases, an older measurement of the variable\\nof interest can be used as an auxiliary variable when attempting to produce more current estimates.\\nCluster sampling Sometimes it is more cost-effective to select\\nrespondents in groups. Sampling is often clustered by geography, or by time periods. For instance,\\nif surveying households within a city, we might choose to select 100 city blocks and\\nthen interview every household within the selected blocks.\\nClustering can reduce travel and administrative costs. In the example above, an interviewer\\ncan make a single trip to visit several households in one block, rather than having to drive\\nto a different block for each household. It also means that one does not need a sampling\\nframe listing all elements in the target population. Instead, clusters can be chosen from a cluster-level\\nframe, with an element-level frame created only for the selected clusters. In the example\\nabove, the sample only requires a block-level city map for initial selections, and then\\na household-level map of the 100 selected blocks, rather than a household-level map\\nof the whole city. Cluster sampling generally increases the variability\\nof sample estimates above that of simple random sampling, depending on how the clusters differ\\nbetween themselves, as compared with the within-cluster variation. For this reason, cluster sampling\\nrequires a larger sample than SRS to achieve the same level of accuracy - but cost savings\\nfrom clustering might still make this a cheaper option.\\nCluster sampling is commonly implemented as multistage sampling. This is a complex form\\nof cluster sampling in which two or more levels of units are embedded one in the other. The\\nfirst stage consists of constructing the clusters that will be used to sample from. In the second\\nstage, a sample of primary units is randomly selected from each cluster. In following stages,\\nin each of those selected clusters, additional samples of units are selected, and so on.\\nAll ultimate units selected at the last step of this procedure are then surveyed. This\\ntechnique, thus, is essentially the process of taking random subsamples of preceding random\\nsamples. Multistage sampling can substantially reduce\\nsampling costs, where the complete population list would need to be constructed. By eliminating\\nthe work involved in describing clusters that are not selected, multistage sampling can\\nreduce the large costs associated with traditional cluster sampling. However, each sample may\\nnot be a full representative of the whole population.\\nQuota sampling In quota sampling, the population is first\\nsegmented into mutually exclusive sub-groups, just as in stratified sampling. Then judgement\\nis used to select the subjects or units from each segment based on a specified proportion.\\nFor example, an interviewer may be told to sample 200 females and 300 males between the\\nage of 45 and 60. It is this second step which makes the technique\\none of non-probability sampling. In quota sampling the selection of the sample is non-random.\\nFor example interviewers might be tempted to interview those who look most helpful.\\nThe problem is that these samples may be biased because not everyone gets a chance of selection.\\nThis random element is its greatest weakness and quota versus probability has been a matter\\nof controversy for several years. Accidental sampling\\nAccidental sampling is a type of nonprobability sampling which involves the sample being drawn\\nfrom that part of the population which is close to hand. That is, a population is selected\\nbecause it is readily available and convenient. It may be through meeting \\nthe person or including a person in the sample when one meets them or chosen by finding them\\nthrough technological means such as the internet or through phone. The researcher using such\\na sample cannot scientifically make generalizations about the total population from this sample\\nbecause it would not be representative enough. For example, if the interviewer were to conduct\\nsuch a survey at a shopping center early in the morning on a given day, the people that\\nhe/she could interview would be limited to those given there at that given time, which\\nwould not represent the views of other members of society in such an area, if the survey\\nwere to be conducted at different times of day and several times per week. This type\\nof sampling is most useful for pilot testing. Several important considerations for researchers\\nusing convenience samples include: Are there controls within the research design\\nor experiment which can serve to lessen the impact of a non-random convenience sample,\\nthereby ensuring the results will be more representative of the population?\\nIs there good reason to believe that a particular convenience sample would or should respond\\nor behave differently than a random sample from the same population?\\nIs the question being asked by the research one that can adequately be answered using\\na convenience sample? In social science research, snowball sampling\\nis a similar technique, where existing study subjects are used to recruit more subjects\\ninto the sample. Some variants of snowball sampling, such as respondent driven sampling,\\nallow calculation of selection probabilities and are probability sampling methods under\\ncertain conditions. Line-intercept sampling\\nLine-intercept sampling is a method of sampling elements in a region whereby an element is\\nsampled if a chosen line segment, called a "transect", intersects the element.\\nPanel sampling Panel sampling is the method of first selecting\\na group of participants through a random sampling method and then asking that group for information\\nseveral times over a period of time. Therefore, each participant is interviewed at two or\\nmore time points; each period of data collection is called a "wave". The method was developed\\nby sociologist Paul Lazarsfeld in 1938 as a means of studying political campaigns. This\\nlongitudinal sampling-method allows estimates of changes in the population, for example\\nwith regard to chronic illness to job stress to weekly food expenditures. Panel sampling\\ncan also be used to inform researchers about within-person health changes due to age or\\nto help explain changes in continuous dependent variables such as spousal interaction. There\\nhave been several proposed methods of analyzing panel data, including MANOVA, growth curves,\\nand structural equation modeling with lagged effects.\\nReplacement of selected units Sampling schemes may be without replacement\\nor with replacement. For example, if we catch fish, measure them, and immediately return\\nthem to the water before continuing with the sample, this is a WR design, because we might\\nend up catching and measuring the same fish more than once. However, if we do not return\\nthe fish to the water, this becomes a WOR design.\\nSample size Formulas, tables, and power function charts\\nare well known approaches to determine sample size.\\nSteps for using sample size tables Postulate the effect size of interest, ,\\nand . Check sample size tableSelect the table corresponding\\nto the selected  Locate the row corresponding to the desired\\npower Locate the column corresponding to the estimated\\neffect size. The intersection of the column and row is\\nthe minimum sample size required. Sampling and data collection\\nGood data collection involves: Following the defined sampling process\\nKeeping the data in time order Noting comments and other contextual events\\nRecording non-responses Errors in sample surveys\\nSurvey results are typically subject to some error. Total errors can be classified into\\nsampling errors and non-sampling errors. The term "error" here includes systematic biases\\nas well as random errors. Sampling errors and biases\\nSampling errors and biases are induced by the sample design. They include:\\nSelection bias: When the true selection probabilities differ from those assumed in calculating the\\nresults. Random sampling error: Random variation in\\nthe results due to the elements in the sample being selected at random.\\nNon-sampling error Non-sampling errors are other errors which\\ncan impact the final survey estimates, caused by problems in data collection, processing,\\nor sample design. They include: Overcoverage: Inclusion of data from outside\\nof the population. Undercoverage: Sampling frame does not include\\nelements in the population. Measurement error: e.g. when respondents misunderstand\\na question, or find it difficult to answer. Processing error: Mistakes in data coding.\\nNon-response: Failure to obtain complete data from all selected individuals.\\nAfter sampling, a review should be held of the exact process followed in sampling, rather\\nthan that intended, in order to study any effects that any divergences might have on\\nsubsequent analysis. A particular problem is that of non-response.\\nTwo major types of nonresponse exist: unit nonresponse and item nonresponse. In survey\\nsampling, many of the individuals identified as part of the sample may be unwilling to\\nparticipate, not have the time to participate, or survey administrators may not have been\\nable to contact them. In this case, there is a risk of differences, between respondents\\nand nonrespondents, leading to biased estimates of population parameters. This is often addressed\\nby improving survey design, offering incentives, and conducting follow-up studies which make\\na repeated attempt to contact the unresponsive and to characterize their similarities and\\ndifferences with the rest of the frame. The effects can also be mitigated by weighting\\nthe data when population benchmarks are available or by imputing data based on answers to other\\nquestions. Nonresponse is particularly a problem in internet\\nsampling. Reasons for this problem include improperly designed surveys, over-surveying,\\nand the fact that potential participants hold Survey weights\\nIn many situations the sample fraction may be varied by stratum and data will have to\\nbe weighted to correctly represent the population. Thus for example, a simple random sample of\\nindividuals in the United Kingdom might include some in remote Scottish islands who would\\nbe inordinately expensive to sample. A cheaper method would be to use a stratified sample\\nwith urban and rural strata. The rural sample could be under-represented in the sample,\\nbut weighted up appropriately in the analysis to compensate.\\nMore generally, data should usually be weighted if the sample design does not give each individual\\nan equal chance of being selected. For instance, when households have equal selection probabilities\\nbut one person is interviewed from within each household, this gives people from large\\nhouseholds a smaller chance of being interviewed. This can be accounted for using survey weights.\\nSimilarly, households with more than one telephone line have a greater chance of being selected\\nin a random digit dialing sample, and weights can adjust for this.\\nWeights can also serve other purposes, such as helping to correct for non-response.\\nMethods of producing random samples Random number table\\nMathematical algorithms for pseudo-random number generators\\nPhysical randomization devices such as coins, playing cards or sophisticated devices such\\nas ERNIE History\\nRandom sampling by using lots is an old idea, mentioned several times in the Bible. In 1786\\nPierre Simon Laplace estimated the population of France by using a sample, along with ratio\\nestimator. He also computed probabilistic estimates of the error. These were not expressed\\nas modern confidence intervals but as the sample size that would be needed to achieve\\na particular upper bound on the sampling error and assumed that his sample was random. Alexander\\nIvanovich Chuprov introduced sample surveys to Imperial Russia in the 1870s.\\nIn the USA the 1936 Literary Digest prediction of a Republican win in the presidential election\\nwent badly awry, due to severe bias [1]. More than two million people responded to the study\\nwith their names obtained through magazine subscription lists and telephone directories.\\nIt was not appreciated that these lists were heavily biased towards Republicans and the\\nresulting sample, though very large, was deeply flawed.\\nSee also HorvitzThompson estimator\\nOfficial statistics Ratio estimator\\nSampling Sampling error\\nNotes The textbook by Groves et alia provides an\\noverview of survey methodology, including recent literature on questionnaire development\\xa0:\\nRobert Groves, et alia. Survey methodology Second edition of the first edition ISBN 0-471-48348-6.\\nThe other books focus on the statistical theory of survey sampling and require some knowledge\\nof basic statistics, as discussed in the following textbooks:\\nDavid S. Moore and George P. McCabe. "Introduction to the practice of statistics". W.H. Freeman\\n& Company. ISBN 0-7167-6282-X. Freedman, David; Pisani, Robert; Purves, Roger.\\nStatistics. New York: Norton. ISBN\\xa00-393-92972-8.\\xa0 The elementary book by Scheaffer et alia uses\\nquadratic equations from high-school algebra: Scheaffer, Richard L., William Mendenhal and\\nR. Lyman Ott. Elementary survey sampling, Fifth Edition. Belmont: Duxbury Press, 1996.\\nMore mathematical statistics is required for Lohr, for Srndal et alia, and \\nfor Cochran: Cochran, William G.. Sampling techniques.\\nWiley. ISBN\\xa00-471-16240-X.\\xa0 Lohr, Sharon L.. Sampling: Design and analysis.\\nDuxbury. ISBN\\xa00-534-35361-4.\\xa0 Srndal, Carl-Erik, and Swensson, Bengt,\\nand Wretman, Jan. Model assisted survey sampling. Springer-Verlag. ISBN\\xa00-387-40620-4.\\xa0\\nThe historically important books by Deming and Kish remain valuable for insights for\\nsocial scientists: Deming, W. Edwards. Some Theory of Sampling.\\nDover Publications. ISBN\\xa00-486-64684-X. OCLC\\xa0166526.\\xa0 Kish, Leslie Survey Sampling, Wiley, ISBN\\n0-471-10949-5 References Further reading\\nChambers, R L, and Skinner, C J, Analysis of Survey Data, Wiley, ISBN 0-471-89987-9\\nDeming, W. Edwards On probability as a basis for action, The American Statisticia

code_desc: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events. For example, if a student is selected at random from a class, find the probability that Jane will be selected and the probability that a girl will be selected.
video_title: Using Uniform and Non-Uniform Models to Calculate Probability (7SP7a)
video_desc: This lesson explains how to use unitform and non-uniform models to calculate probability. For more videos and instructional resources, visit TenMarks.com.
transcript: Exception
label: Yes

code_desc: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that "increase by 5%" is the same as "multiply by 1.05."
video_title: Rewriting Expressions

code_desc: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.
video_title: Math Antics - Circles Circumference And Area
video_desc: This video teaches clearly about circles, what radius and diameter is?, how circumference is calculated?, what is π (pi) after all?, why pi r squared is used to find area? etc.
transcript: 'Hi!  Welcome to Math Antics. In our last video, we learned about circles and we learned about a special ratio called Pi. In this video, were going to learn how we can use that ratio to calculate the circumference and the area of any circle. The formulas that we use to calculate circumference and area are so important that you should really memorize them. The formula for finding the circumference is: Circumference equals Pi times diameter. And just like most formulas, we use abbreviation: It tells us that if we know the diameter of a circle, \\nall we have to do is The formula for finding the area of a circle is: Area equals Pi times radius squared. Again, we can use abbreviations to make it shorter: Now this is a pretty simple formula too. It tells us that if we know the radius, Well, squaring a number just means multiplying it by itself. For example, 3 squared just means 3 times 3, and 5 squared just means 5 times 5 and r squared just means r times r. So our formula is really just: Oh, and one really important thing to keep in mind is that r squared is NOT the same thing as 2 times r. These two formulas have a lot in common. In each of them, you are multiplying Pi by part of a circle to find either the circumference or the area. In the case of the circumference, you are multiplying Pi times the diameter, and in the case of area, you are multiplying Pi times the radius squared. But do you remember the relationship between the radius and the diameter? Diameter is just 2 times the radius. So we could re-write our formula for circumference like this: Circumference = Pi  2  r. To find the circumference, you take the radius and double it. Then you multiply by Pi to get the final answer. To help you see that difference in action, The only thing we know about this circle is that the radius is 8 meters. First, we use our formula for circumference: C = Pi  d. To get the diameter, we take the radius and we double it. that is, we multiply it by 2. 2  8 = 16, so the diameter is 16 meters. Then, we multiply that by Pi to get the circumference. 16  3.14 = 50.24 So that means that the circumference of this circle is 50.24 meters. That means we multiply it by itself. 8 m  8 m = 64 meters squared. Then we multiply that by Pi. 64  3.14 = 200.96 meters squared. As you can see, \\nthe result we get when we square the radius is very different from the result we get when we we double it. And one of the most important differences is with the units of our answer. Doubling the radius just gives us the diameter, which is a 1-dimensional quantity. So, the answer we get from our formula for circumference is also a 1-dimensional quantity. That makes sense because \\narea is always a 2-dimensional quantity. Remembering that will help you avoid getting these two formulas mixed up. The one that has the radius squared is always for area. But, if we take a slice of the world, right at the equator, that slice is a circle. To do that, we need to know the diameter of the earth. That turns out to be about 12,750 km. Great, then to find the circumference we just need to multiply that diameter times Pi. 12,750  3.14159 = 40,055 km (to the nearest kilometer). No wonder it takes so long to go all the way around the earth! On your mark Get set Go! Whooo - Yes!  3.14 seconds quicker than last time.  Yes! Well, using our formula, we start by squaring the radius. But, the problem didnt give us the radius it gave us the diameter, so we have to calculate the radius from the diameter. The radius is just half of the diameter, so we just need to divide the diameter by 2. 24 inches divided by 2 gives us 12 inches for the radius. And now that we know the radius, we need to square it. 12 in  12 in = 144 inches squared. Next, we just multiply that by Pi. 144  3.14 is 452.16. So, the total area of the pizza is 452.16 square inches. Alright, so know you know how to find the circumference and the area of any circle. All you need to do is remember the formulas: Circumference equals Pi times diameter, and Area equals Pi times radius squared. so be sure to try some of the exercises problems. Learn more at www.mathantics.com '
label: Yes

code_desc: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example: If a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1/10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9 3/4 inches long in the center of a door that is 27 1/2 inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; this estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

code_desc: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. code_desc: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

code_desc: Understand that integers can be divided, provided that the divisor is not zero, and every quotient of integers (with non-zero divisor) is a rational number. If p and q are integers, then -(p/q) = (-p)/q = p/(-q). Interpret quotients of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

code_desc: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example: If a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1/10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9 3/4 inches long in the center of a door that is 27 1/2 inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; this estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

code_desc: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions. For example, estimate the mean word length in a book by randomly sampling words from the book; predict the winner of a school election based on randomly sampled survey data. Gauge how far off the estimate or prediction might be.

video_desc: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. CC standard: 3.NBT.A.2.

code_desc: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

code_desc: Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events. For example, use random digits as a simulation tool to approximate the answer to the question: If 40% of donors have type A blood, what is the probability that it will take at least 4 donors to find one with type A blood?
video_title: [7SP8c-11] Using Simulations for Compound Events - Common Core Standard
